section.title: about unique objects
section.para: A uuiduuid or universally unique identifier universally unique identifieris used to uniquely identify objects. This 128bit standard allows anyone to create a unique uuid.

section.title: /sbin/vol_id
section.para: Below we use the vol_idvol_id(1) utility to display the uuid of an ext3 file system.

section.title: /lib/udev/vold_id
section.para: Red Hat Enterprise Linux 5 puts vol_id in /lib/udev/vol_id, which is not in the $PATH. The syntax is also a bit different from Debian/Ubuntu.

section.title: /sbin/tune2fs
section.para: We can also use tune2fstune2fs(1) to find the uuid of a file system.

section.title: uuid in /etc/fstab
section.para: You can use the uuid to make sure that a volume is universally uniquely identified in /etc/fstab. The device name can change depending on the disk devices that are present at boot time, but a uuid never changes.
First we use tune2fs to find the uuid.
Then we check that it is properly added to /etc/fstab, the uuid replaces the variable devicename /dev/sdc1.
Now we can mount the volume using the mountpoint defined in /etc/fstab.
The real test now, is to remove /dev/sdb from the system, reboot the machine and see what happens. After the reboot, the disk previously known as /dev/sdc is now /dev/sdb.
And thanks to the uuid in /etc/fstab, the mountpoint is mounted on the same disk as before.

section.title: uuid in menu.lst
section.para: Recent incarnations of the Ubuntu distribution will use a uuid to identify the root file system. This example shows how a root=/dev/sda1 is replaced with a uuid.
section.screen: title Ubuntu 9.10, kernel 2.6.31-19-generic uuid f001ba5d-9077-422a-9634-8d23d57e782a kernel /boot/vmlinuz-2.6.31-19-generic \ root=UUID=f001ba5d-9077-422a-9634-8d23d57e782a ro quiet splash initrd /boot/initrd.img-2.6.31-19-generic
